Great, now that you've powered the circuit and observed the DMM readings, let's take a look at what happens during the circuit's operation.

Click Continue to take a look.

Voltage is available before the toggle switch in the circuit.

A path to ground is available after the push-button switch and to relay contact (E).

When the toggle switch is closed, voltage is available:
  • In the circuit ending at the open push button switch
  • From the toggle switch to the push button
  • To the toggle switch through relay contact (A)

A path to ground is still available after the push button switch and to relay contact (E).

When the push button switch is closed, current flows through the relay coil.

This generates a magnetic field, represented here as lines of force.
The magnetic field generated by current flowing through the relay coil pulls the relay armature plate in towards the coil, and closes the contacts.

Current is now allowed to flow through the bulbs and closed relay contacts.

The relay coil continues to hold the contacts closed with the magnetic field produced.

As the push button switch is released, the magnetic field begins to collapse.

As the magnetic field collapses, the magnetic lines of force pass over the coil and a reverse voltage is induced.

The voltage will be of opposite polarity to the previous example.
